instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PM_DSW_PWRGD: What is PM_DSW_PWRGD? The "PM_DSW_PWRGD" signal in a MacBook stands for "Deep Sleep Well Power Good‚Äù and is required for the machine to power on & post..
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.
definitions.U6100: What is U6100? this is an SPI ROM chip that holds the BIOS which is necessary for the machine to POST or try and power on..
definitions.820-3435: What is 820-3435? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
So i have a vomit damaged 3437 that came in fully dead no green light. Removed the Jtag connector, ran some wires and replaced SMC and some other small resistors. Now I have green light and <SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL> but no <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>.

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> - 8.6V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> - 5V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> - 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> - 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> - 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL> - 3.3V

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message: The usual, corroded resistors in <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> data lines, pin 8 of <CHIP>U1950</CHIP>, clock chip....Check for a pulse on L7520 right after connecting AC? Check all coils for short to GND?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message: All Resistors around the Bios Chip Check and look clean, <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> is getting its voltage and isnt fucked, Check with another clock chip off a working board and still the same problems, I am getting a quick pulse on L7520 and all coils are fine

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Check if there are pulses on other coils too. CPU Vcore coming on shortly too?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Yep im getting pulses of Vcore. up to right around 1.1V or so

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message: All power is ok then. Still check continuity to all resistors in <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> circuit. Check from <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> to the 4 resistors near the CPU. Where was the corrosion?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message: The Corrosion was right on top of the JTAG connector and right around the SMC area. What 4 resistors around the CPU?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message: <RESISTOR>R6110</RESISTOR>-13 see page 46 and beep out all traces and resistors in the termination circuit. 16 resistors and all the traces

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Tested all the termination circuit. Then pulled a BIOS chip from a dead board to test. We now have a working machine. Now to find a 3437 Clean ME Bios

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Hmmm, read the original chip and use the ME region from there. ME is not corrupt probably.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message: I read the original chip and stole that ME Region but the computer was back to being dead with that ME region. Put in a new ME region from here [url]http://www.win-raid.com/t596f39-Intel-Management-Engine-Drivers-Firmware-amp-System-Tools.html[/url] and everything is working fine now. Thanks again Duke. So if a machine does not see the BIOS it will do the weird power cycling?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Also a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> SMC works fine on a 3437 Board. Just ASD thinks its an 11' air not a 13" Air.
